thread.title: Jim Walker, Asianomics: Possibility of global markets seeing better growth in 2017 than 2016
thread.title_full: Jim Walker, Asianomics: Possibility of global markets seeing better growth in 2017 than 2016

author: FE Online
title: Jim Walker, Asianomics: Possibility of global markets seeing better growth in 2017 than 2016
text:
Jim Walker, Asianomics: Possibility of global markets seeing better growth in 2017 than 2016 Jim Walker, Asianomics: Possibility of global markets seeing better growth in 2017 than 2016 Jim Walker, Founder and Chief Economist of Asianomics Group Ltd on Tuesday said that there is a possibility of global markets seeing better growth in 2017 than in 2016. By: FE Online | Updated: February 21, 2017 12:53 PM Speaking about commodities he said, “We don’t expect much more of an upside surprise from commodity prices. 
Jim Walker, Founder and Chief Economist of Asianomics Group Ltd on Tuesday said that there is a possibility of global markets seeing better growth in 2017 than in 2016. In a conversation with CNBC TV 18, Walker said, “Consumer confidence is slightly concerning. Central bankers and policy makers are focusing too much on consumer prices. They will be forced to tighten the policy if consumer prices pick up”. “Exports growth to be a drag if dollar remains strong. There is plenty of support for a weak dollar,” he added. Speaking about commodities he said, “We don’t expect much more of an upside surprise from commodity prices. We had taken off short on commodities in 2016. Stabilisation in commodity prices wasn’t a surprise,” he told the business news channel. 
Meanwhile, Asian stocks held ground on Tuesday though Chinese equities surged to a fresh 2-1/2 month high as domestic funds piled into financial counters on expectations the world’s second biggest economy may have turned a corner. MSCI’s broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan was up 0.2 percent on Tuesday and held below a 19-month peak hit last Thursday. The index is up more than 11 percent since Dec. 23, which marked the trough in a selloff triggered by Donald Trump’s surprise win at the US election in November. 
With US markets closed for the Presidents Holiday on Monday, Asian markets have had few global cues off which to trade. European markets are broadly expected to follow in Asia’s wake and seen drifting in a narrow band.
